715079f-a.text:
346 Esast 114th Street, south side, west of First Avenue. This is a one-story frame shack at the south end of a vacant lot, left by demolition of a three-story frame house. In the background is a three-story frame house at the rear of 343 East 113th
Street.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York,
Negative No. 248

720691f-a.text:
JJefferson Park- Three views in a southwestward direction progressively from East 114th Street, showing the new swimming
pool and hard-ball courts.
Buildings aid gas nolders in the background are on the west side of First Avenue, at Eastlllth Street. The park is on the east side of the Avenue and extenes from 1l1th to 114th
Streets.
138
Views: 1-2-3
Gift of Committee on Housing
Charity Orga ization Society

720692f-a.text:
Jefferson Park: A view showing children wading in a shallow pool on the north side of the Park that lies east of First Ave. The photograpdher is viewing northwestward to show buildings on East 114th Street. The 5 story structure with a cross mounted atop same is given as a M.E. Church (no name) by Bromley's Atlas of 1922. It is in this vicinity that the street carnivals for the Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel are held; the Church being around the corner on East 115th Street.
July 1933.
George L. Balgue.
A photograph showing the bandstand that is located in the east1y portion of the Park. Subsecuently the East River Drive will
be constructed at the left.

720692f-b.text:
Jefferson Park: A view showing children wading in a shallow pool on the north side of the Park that lies east of First Ave. The photograpdher is viewing northwestward to show buildings on East 114th Street. Carmel are held; the Church being around the corner on East 115th Street.
July 1933.
George L. Balgue.
A photograph showing the bandstand that is located in the east1y portion of the Park. Subsecuently the East River Drive will
be constructed at the left.

731614f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Vendors of toy balloons, at
First Avenue and 114th Street. The view is north.
The woman is wearing a "Eelen Wills" eyeshade; these were very
much in fashion the preceding year.
July 16, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A man and his son buying votive candles. Notice that refreshments
are also for sale here.
July 16, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

731619f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Parade, marching south on First Avenue past the filling station adjoining the S.w. corner of 109th Street. A woman in the centen of the picture is carrying wax votive images of a head and an abdomen. These will be carried into the church and laid at Our Lady's altar. The filling station in the background was built since 1925, replacing three old frame sheds. The angle made by the building on the left is due to the property line, which at this point coincided with the S.W. side of Roosevelt Road, a country
road long since obliterated.
July 16, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  Neg RR0S
(2)
Parade, entering and turning south on First Aveme at 115th
Street.
Jefferson Park lies on the east side of First Avenue from
114th to 111th Streets.
July 16, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  i DE2:
V11S  ( 2H EE1: M  .  E
(3)
Parade, moving east on 114th Street opposite N.W. corner of First Avenue. The girl in the foreground is carrying a giant
oandle on her head.
July 16, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
i EE 25  iP  -44-  ) 7  (S4 4( :47  1uS  1177
